Another way to think of the track question is this:

Imagine you and another person both start at the start line and agree to run a two lap race. You're out of shape and they're a very good runner, but you're slowly improving with their training and you like the challenge.

You line up at the start line, do a countdown, and then start running. You notice that the other person quickly gets away, easily outrunning you. Once you get to the end of the bend you see they've reached the end of the straight, twice as far as you! You then decide to only focus on your running.

Once you get onto the final straight of your first lap you're feeling pretty good, thinking to yourself that you can keep this pace up for the whole two lap race. As you're approaching the end of your first lap, you turn around and see them running you down! You and the other person cross the line at the exact same time, you having completed your first lap, or half the race, and them having completed the whole race of two laps.

How fast do you need to go on your second lap to tie them at the finish line?

Here it makes more intuitive sense that, since you both are at the exact same line with them having finished the two lap race while you've only completed one, you've run out of time to catch up to them to make your average speed twice that of your first lap, or 2V, which happens to be the very pace they were running because they're very fit and you're not. You would need to travel twice the distance in 0 time.

Simplifying problem 2 with no advanced algebra: The trick is that people intuitively think that 2 laps means 2 runs, where you clock each run. The solution is then obvious... But it's a trick question: he's not asking you to do 2 runs, he's asking you to do 1 run, that consist of 2 laps, where the total speed of the run is double the speed of the first lap in that run. Since the time it will take to complete the run will always be greater than the time it takes to complete the first lap of the run, the answer is that its impossible. It will always take more time to complete 2 laps than it takes to complete 1 lap in the same run. No need for any equation here. Common sense, trick question. So here is the simplified version of the question: Can you complete a whole run faster than it took you to complete half of the run? The answer is obviously no. About the laps problem:

The general formula for calculating an average speed is total distance divided by total time. Vavg=(d1+d2)/(t1+t2). If, and ONLY if, t1 and t2 are equal, the formula can be simplified to Vavg=(v1+v2)/2. In this case, t1 and t2 are very different, because you spend a lot more time in the first lap (since you are slower) than in the second lap. However, since the distance you are running on both laps is the same, the formula can be simplified to this: Vavg=2/((1/v1)+(1/v2))

If your feet, at the lowest point, where it's most like your feet were walking on the ground, were moving backwards relative to the ground, you would be going slower than walking. But, in extremely steep hill-climb situations with a heavily-loaded bike, you might want a really low gear, and you could build one. This riddle is about gearing.

Now, one way to express the gear ratios of a bicycle is to state the size of the imaginary wheel you would be pedalling on a direct-drive tricycle or an old-timey high-wheel bike. If your 26-inch bike wheel goes around twice each time you pedal, it's like pedalling a 52-inch tricycle.

It's what our host was talking about when they said "gears and ratios and wheel size", and it is math.

(It isn't all that hard, really. Count the number of teeth on the front chainwheel and on the rear cog. Relate them to find how many times the wheel will go around for each time the pedals go around. Take the wheel size times that.)

But the point here is that the radius of the imaginary wheel size would have to be LESS than the length of the cranks the pedals are mounted on, in order to get the pulling-backwards thing to work.

Imagine a direct-drive railroad bicycle. Keep making the wheel smaller so you can pull heavier loads. When it is so small that your feet go down past the surface of the rail, they will be moving backwards at the bottom like the flange on a railroad wheel.

For the people who are confused by the second riddle, just use numbers!

Assume the following:
- The lap distance "d" is 10 meters.
d = 10 m
- Your speed in the first lap "V1" is 1 meter per second.
V1 = 1 m/s
- You have to run the 2 laps at an average speed "Vavg" of 2 meters per second
Vavg = 2V1 = 2×1 = 2 m/s

Remember that V = d/t
So:
t1 = d/V1 = 10×1 = 10 s
t(total) = 2d/Vavg = 2×10/2 = 10 s

Notice that the time needed for both laps (10 s) equals the time that you spent in the first lap alone (10 s)!!!

So basically, you have to complete the second lap in 0 seconds to be able to achieve Vavg = 2V1 !!!

This wasn't even a riddle, anyone who knows the basic logic of how reality functions knows the answer intuitively, and that logic can be expressed using elementary math.

Not to mention "speed" and "velocity" are different things, although velocity is dependent on speed. Velocity is a vector quantity that refers to the rate at which an object changes its position, speed is a scalar quantity that refers to how fast an object is moving. In any case I’ll explain why traveling 3 times faster is the answer, and how to get the time of the second lap needed to achieve that using the formula for speed, then give an example.

The goal is to have an average speed after 2 laps which is equal to double the speed of your first lap, and speed is your average distance over time. “Average” is the concept that there is something which is the most common in a set of things, we quantify an average by quantifying a set of things then taking their sum and dividing by the number of variables in the set. So the average speed that someone takes to run a lap around a course using data from 2 laps would be half of the the sum of those speeds.

In order to have an average speed that’s twice as fast as half of the sum of your 2 speeds, you need the sum of those speeds to be 4 times faster than the speed of your first lap. That means that you indeed need to be 3 times faster on your second lap than on your first. Just like I answered on your last video, and like you initially said on this video you made after reading many comments pointing that out.

To solve this mathematically you first have to consider the situation. In the proposed question distance is constant, because it’s the same in both laps around the track. So obviously the factor that has to change is time. As any elementary school student can tell you: If you divide something by a number 1/2 the size it’ll have a quotient twice as large, and obviously the quotient of a dividend divided by the quotient of thrice itself and some divisor results in a value 1/3 of the size of the divisor.

To put it mathematically:
(1st s + 2nd s) / 2 = 2*1st s ⇒ 1st s + 2nd s = 2*2*1st s ⇒ 2nd s = 4*1st s - 1st s = 3*1st s (3s)
(s + 3s) / 2 = 4s / 2 = 2s
s = d / t ⇒ 3s = 3d / t = d / (t / 3)
s = d / t ⇒ t = d / s
Time of second lap = d / (3d / t ) = dt / 3d = t / 3

I'll give you an easy example using the units for speed I grew up with, miles per hour (mph AKA mi/h):
If your distance around the track is 1 mile (1mi) and you do the first lap in 15 minutes (15m), then given that there are 60 minutes in an hour your speed is 4mph.
d = 1mi, t = 15m, h = m / 60
s = 1mi / 15m = 1mi / (15/60)h = (1/0.25)mi / h = 4mph

Thus double your speed is 8mph, and triple your speed is 12mph.
2s = 2*4mph = 8mph
3s = 3*4mph = 12mph

Therefore the time you need to do the 2nd lap in is 5 minutes.
h = m / 60 ⇒ m = h*60
1mi / (12mi / 1h) = 1mi / (12mi / 60m) = 1mi / (0.2mi/m) = (1/0.2)m = 5m
1mi / 5m = 1mi / (5/60)h = (1/(1/12))mi / h = 12mph

If that was too confusing for anyone because I used miles and mph you can make your own euro version of this same example by taking triple your usual time for a kilometer to get a kph for your first lap that makes it possible for you to do it in real life.

Let’s call the average speed of each lap: V1=D/T1, and V2=D/T2. Distance is unchanged.

This means that if you run the same distance 3 times faster than the first lap, the mean speed doubles the speed of the original lap.

The actual definition of average speed, involves the total distance which is 2D
in the total time which is T. Is easy to tell that T=T1+T2.
Now if you use this you have that
Vavg=2D/(T1+T2), and here is the tricky part. Since you want this to be 2V1 then by solving you have:
2D/(T1+T2)=2*(D/T1), So you’ll arrive to T1=T1+T2,which can only be achieved if T2=0.
This in short means that you run at an infinte speed in your second lap, which is physically imposible.

Remember don’t confuse MEAN SPEED with AVERAGE SPEED, they are only the same when the speed remains constant during the motion. I hope that this helps. Grettings.

The running two laps - 2V = 2d/t problem is hard to grasp so I did some actual examples and I now see it.


Let's say your first lap is at 1 mph. You cover .25 miles in .25 hours (15 minutes).


Let's say your second lap is at 3 mph. You cover .25 miles in .083333 hrs (5 minutes)


Your combined half mile time equals .25 + .08333 = .3333333 hrs (20 minutes).


Velocity is distance/time so .5 / .333333 = 1.5 mph



This is NOT twice your first velocity - we are looking for 2 mph.


Skip ahead to running you second lap at 6,000 mph.


In your second lap you cover .25 miles in 0.15 seconds (.000041666 hours).


Your combined half mile time is .25 + .000041666 = .2500416666 Hours


Divide distance over time (like before) .5 / .250041666 = 1.9996667 MPH - Not quite 2 MPH.


As a matter of fact, you'll never reach 2.0 MPH no matter how fast you go.

The runner riddle is a classic. Another way of telling this is: Suppose two people want to travel between two cities A and B. One guy has a bicycle so he starts peddling away (suppose at 30km/h). The other guy has nothing, but he is lucky: he can get a lift in a Porsche 911 at 200 km/h until halfway between A and B. That is because during the second half of the track, he wastes all the advantage that he had by going half as slow as the other guy. This is an important lesson: it is not the quick win or the fast starter that wins, it is the one who endures all the way ! :-) Everybody who does sports knows this: the price is given at the arrival, not halfway. The speed riddle is not actually a riddle, the answer is in indeed 3V¹ as you initially thought.


(V¹ + V²)/2 = 2V¹


V¹ + V² = 4V¹
V² = 3V¹


Now consider that the distance (d) is actually the same on both laps, because they are both laps around the same exact field. So the distance doesn't change, what changes is the time it takes to complete the distance:


V¹ = d / t¹
V² = d / t²


then, from V² = 3V¹ we get:


d / t² = 3d / t¹


d * t¹ = 3d * t²


t¹ = 3t²


So it's as simple as that; you have to run such that the time it takes to run your first lap is 3 times as long as the time it takes to run your second lap.


Example:


If I run a 1km lap in 3 hours, my speed is 0.33 km/h
If I run a second lap in 1 hour, my speed is 1 km/h


My average speed for both laps is 0.66 km/h which is twice my speed in the first lap.

For 2:44

v(t) is a function speed vs. time.

T1 is the time needed for the first, slower lap,
T2 is the time needed for the second, faster lap.

The general formula for AVG speed is:

Va=(integral[0...T1] v(t)dt + integral[T1...T1+T2] v(t)dt) / (T1+T2)

We adapt this formula to the given problem:

Constant speed V1 during T1.
Constant speed V2 during T2.

V1=D1/T1
V2=D2/T2

where D1=D2=D, the distance D of one lap is the same for both speeds.

Put this stuff into the general AVG speed formula, you will end up with:

Va=(2*D)/(T1+T2)

and Va MUST be equal to 2*V1, this leads to an equation looking like this:

1/(T1+T2) = 1/T1 or T1+T2=T1

which can only be satisfied if T2=0.

Theoretical answer to the Running Question-

Let the circumference of the ground be 'd'

average speed = total distance/total time

therefore

let the velocity for first lap be v1 and velocity for second lap be v2

time for first lap be t1 and time for second lap be t2

t1= d/v1
t2= d/v2

total distance = 2d (circled the ground 2 times)

average velocity = 2d/(d/v1 + d/v2)
=[2d(v1v2)]/[d(v1 + v2)] (d gets cancelled out)
=2v1v2/(v1+v1)

now this velocity should be equal to 2v1

therefore 2v1=2v1v2/(v1+v2)
= 2v1(v1+v2)=2v1v2 (2v1 gets cancelled from both sides)
= v1 + v2 = v2 (v2 gets cancelled from both sides)
= v1 = 0

but if v1 = 0 the time will become infinite, so practically this is not possible unless v2 = infinite

But going deep into the terminology used

He said "what will be the velocity"

velocity is a vector quantity and it is equal to displacement/time

while circling a ground we are coming back to our original position so displacement = 0 hence velocity in both the cases would be zero

the correct terminology here would have been speed or angular velocity (omega)

I would like to clarify the meaning of average velocity. Yes the average
velocity is the average of velocities but the average has to be
computed in the correct way. The average of two numbers x and y is not
always (x+y)/2. In general its p*x+(1-p)*y where p is a number smaller
than one.

For example, we may attribute more weight to the number y so that the
average z may be written as z=x/3+2y/3 with 1/3=p and 2/3=1-1/3=1-p in
the formula given above. Let's take an example. A sprinter runing at a
reasonable speed v1 for 2 minutes. that decides to run at a faster speed
v2 a tenth of a second before he reaches the finish line. A duration
so small that you can't even see that he moved that much. Would it be
reasonable to say that the average speed is (v1+v2)/2 ? No ! You hardly
even saw him moving at v2 so you can't give the same weight to v1 and
v2. If you did then you would be giving him the same average velocity
as if he had done 1 minute at v1 and 1 minute at v2. But how should we
attribute a reasonable weight to v2 ? Easy ! You divide the duration in
which the sprinter has a speed v2, which we shall call t2, by the total
time (t1+t2). Thus in this case t2/(t1+t2) is so small that the average
speed would resemble alot more the speed of the runner during the 2
minutes. Of course if the sprinter started to run at near the speed of
light during that tenth of a second than it might not be so negligeable.
You would have to give the guy some credit for acheiving such a speed !

Two comments: first, the cylinder on the slope: dry uniform-size dry sand partially filling the cylinder would be a possible valid answer. Sand will avalanche if its surface slope exceeds a critical angle. Initially, the cylinder would roll, and the sand would move as a unit, creating a counterweight that would slow, then stop the cylinder. If the amount of sand was just right, it would avalanche just as the cylinder comes to a stop, thereby reducing the counterweight and allowing the cylinder to recommence rolling. Reperat.

Second, the bicycle: it depends on the gear ratio AND the pulling force. A/ Normal bike/weakish string: bike stays still (ie, string to weak to overcome back wheel friction; B/ Normal bike/cable pulled by D9 caterpillar: bike dragged backward (back wheel skidding); C/ Bike with very very low gear/string or cable: bike initially moves forward, then stops (string) or is dragged backward (cable).

Derek, I really have a problem with your answer to the velocity question.

While I agree with you, in terms of using a secant line to determine the "average velocity" it will be impossible to make the average velocity twice v(1); if we define v(1)=f'(t)=1 and v(2)=g'(t)=3 then it makes sense to add the two functions together and simply get v(average)=(f'(t)+g'(t))/2=(1+3)/2=2.

This makes sense, since if we were to take the definite integrals of f' and g' we get the distance traveled in those two laps (where t(1)=3*t(2) and taking the integrals from 0 to 1 and 0 to 1/3 respectively to f' and g')

While I completely see why you would want to use a secant line; I'd actually argue that that isn't really an "average" velocity any more than v(1) is an average velocity. In your riddle you seemed to imply that you'd be running at a constant rate, and there would be no need to do anything but interpret v(1) or v(2) as anything but derivatives of a specific function. As a result, I think its fair to say just exactly how you're going to determine what the "average" velocity is, and I think using the derivative definition (instead of a secant line definition) is equally valid; but a different, mode of approaching the question. Additionally, it gives you a meaningful answer to the question. After all; if you were able to run around the track in an infinitesimally small amount of time, then you could just as easily say that you're running around the track 3, 4, or any number of "times faster" than the first lap.

I don't see any reason why the approach of averaging the value of derivatives at all points is not a valid and meaningful solution to the question; and I don't understand why you've decided to suggest that its not a valid answer given the phrasing of your question since you didn't specify the precise definition of "average velocity." After all; if two independent people ran around the track and you wanted to get the average velocity of both of those people then the sensible answer that most people would reach for would be to add the two velocities (derivative functions) together and divide by two. I think you've created quite a bit of ambiguity in this question by not being precise with what you're asking.

And both these statements are correct for the assumption that v1 = d/t1; but we're saying that we will run a consistent speed, not 2 different speeds. We have different assumptions for the "riddle":
d = d1 = d2;
2*v1 = (v1 + v2) / 2 (we have to have the same distance or time for both laps to make this assumption)
From the first assumption we find out that v2 = 3*v1 and with the second assumption we can say that d/t2 = 3*d/t1 and say t2= t1/3; So our statements are you have to run the second lap 3 time faster and you have to use 3 times less time then for the first lap. Keeping a constant distance of 300 m: t1 = 300/10 = 30 s and t2 = 300/30 = 10 s. Vas = (300+300)/(30+10) = 15 m/s which is less the 2V1. I think the explanation for the fourth riddle is inadequate, albeit confusing. The solution indispensably requires a discussion of the magnitude and direction of all the forces on the bike, as well as, the rotational motion/torque.

Now days, I have observed that 'Veritasium' is going the 'DNews/Seeker' way! Rarely offering an in-depth explanation! So, I am offering my explanation for the 4th riddle:-

Refer to the diagram shown at 7:42. Lets call the our force applied through string as F1. This is the force applied at the peddle. At first, it seems obvious that this is the only force acting on the bike, but its not so. Consider the torque around the centre point of the forward sprocket.

We can safely say that this torque is F1*R1(Torque is the force applied multiplied by the perpendicular distance, of the point of application of that force, with the axis or point, around which torque is measured).

Now, this torque, is what, will generate the rotational motion around the centre of forward sprocket, and will cause it to move, thus generating a tension(say T) in the bike chain.

So, F1*R1 = T *R3 (because its the same torque)

Now, this force on the chain, which is tension T, will generate the rotational motion or torque around the centre of backward sprocket, causing it to move. When the sprocket tries to move, so does the back wheel/tyre of the bike, causing friction with the surface. This frictional force will be in the forward direction, as the bottom most part of the back wheel/tyre tries to go in the backward direction with respect to the ground. Lets call this frictional force, which acts at the bottom most part of the back wheel/tyre(point where the back wheel/tyre touches the ground surface) as Fr.

So, now, T*R4 = Fr * R2.

From the above two equations, we get:-

Fr = F1*R1*R4/(R2*R3)
which can also be written as:-
Fr = F1*(R1/R2)*(R4/R3)

So, now, we can clearly see that Fr > F1 if R1/R2 > R3/R4

Since, the tension T in the bike chain, cancels itself out, when finding out net forces on the bike, the only two forces on the bike are F1(ours) and Fr(Frictional force at the bottom most point of the back wheel, where it touches the ground). Our force is in the backward direction, and the frictional force is in the forward direction, with respect to the bike.

So, the bike moves backward when Fr < F1, ie when R1/R2 < R3/R4
and forward when Fr > F1, ie when R1/R2 > R3/R4

I still think the race track average speed can be obtained in two different ways and thus has two different answers, one including it being impossible as stated in the video. However your average speed doesn't need to be related to time at all. Averages can be measured exclusively with respect to similar values, so if a car can go 100 ft in roughly 1 second (approximately 68 mph), and a person can go 33+1/3 ft/second (roughly Olympic speeds) then the average speed between these two would be exactly 66+2/3 ft/second because we're not relating the average to time anymore. We're looking at a single instant where their speeds were compared. This is just as valid a result in terms of statistics. We wouldn't ask someone measuring the average speed Olympic runners to figure out how long they spent running at slower speeds throughout their training. Using time here, we'd need to include how many years they spent running at sub-Olympic levels and then incorporate that into our calculation but no one's going to do that. This would skew the data in favor of values that we're not interested in. Instead we ignore the data on these runners that lies outside the relative information we want to know. We want to compare the values to each other runner, not compare their values to the span of their lifetime. Again, because this got long, I have to reiterate that I agree with Veritasium too. If we're taking an average speed of a single runner through multiple iterations of a race, then yes, we'll never get to twice the value. But we aren't necessarily doing that. We can just as validly compare one racer's top speed to another racer's top speed by summing their values and dividing by two, it's just a different KIND of average, but one that still has value none the less.
